hero.title: Documentation: Fundamental Framework
hero.subtitle: How I look at ASX small caps before they enter the weekly list.
hero.intro: This page explains the simple, fundamentals-first framework I use when reviewing ASX small cap companies. The focus is on the business: financial statements, competitive strength, industry dynamics and the path to sustainable profit — not on short-term price moves.

overview.title: Why Start With Fundamentals?
paragraphs: Small cap share prices can move sharply on hype, rumours and short-term news. That noise is hard to predict and even harder to rely on.

Instead of chasing every spike, I start with the basics: how the company makes money, what shape its financial statements are in, how strong its position is against competitors and whether there is a credible way to turn growth into lasting profit and cash flow.

If the underlying business does not make sense, the share price story usually does not last. That is why every company that appears on the weekly watchlist has first passed a simple fundamentals check like the one described on this page.

carousel.title: Four Fundamental Lenses
carousel.subtitle: When I review an ASX small cap, I cycle through these four lenses before it can even qualify for the weekly list.

slides.title: 1. Financial Statements
slides.subtitle: Income, cash flow and the balance sheet.
bullets: Look at revenue over several periods: is it growing, flat or shrinking?
Check gross margins and operating costs to see whether scale could improve profitability.
Compare reported profit to operating cash flow – is the business generating real cash?
Review cash balance, debt and burn rate to understand how much time the company has.

slides.title: 2. Competitive Strength
slides.subtitle: Why this business, not its competitors?
bullets: Clarify who the real customers are and how concentrated they might be.
Ask what problem the company solves and whether the value proposition is concrete or vague.
Look for switching costs, integration effort or regulation that makes customers sticky.
Consider whether the company can defend its pricing or if it is stuck in a race to the bottom.

slides.title: 3. Industry and Market
slides.subtitle: The environment around the company.
bullets: Check whether the market is expanding, stable or shrinking over the next 5–10 years.
Think about cyclicality: how sensitive is the business to rates, sentiment or commodity prices?
Watch for regulatory changes or new technologies that could reshape the playing field.
Ask if the company is likely to gain, keep or lose share as the industry evolves.

slides.title: 4. Profit & Cash Flow Path
slides.subtitle: From growth story to real returns.
bullets: For early-stage names, accept that profits may be small or negative today.
Look at unit economics where available: customer acquisition cost, margins and retention.
Ask how much extra capital is required before the business could fund itself.
Sketch a simple picture of what sustainable free cash flow could look like at maturity.

process.title: Putting It Together: A Simple Flow
steps: Read the latest annual and half-year reports, investor presentations and key announcements.
Write down in plain language how the business makes money and who pays the bills.
Review the financial statements with an eye on cash, debt, dilution and basic unit economics.
Think about competition and industry structure: is there any real edge or tailwind?
Only then decide whether the company is interesting enough to appear on the weekly watchlist.
